questions.question: For a single-engine Class B aeroplane, how does runway slope affect allowable take-off mass, assuming other factors remain constant and not limiting?
options: a. An uphill slope decreases take-off mass
b. Allowable take-off mass is not affected by runway slope
c. A downhill slope decreases allowable take-off mass
d. A downhill slope increases allowable take-off mass
questions.explanation: An uphill runway slope increases the component of weight acting against the take-off direction, requiring more thrust to accelerate. This reduces the allowable take-off mass because the aeroplane needs more runway distance or cannot achieve the required take-off performance with the same mass.

The take-off speeds (rotation speed and speed at 50 ft) are determined by entering the chart with the given conditions: OAT ISA+10, Pressure Altitude 5000 ft, Mass 3400 lb, Headwind 5 kt, Flaps up, and reading the appropriate speeds from the chart.

questions.question: For a Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with no stopway or clearway, the minimum length of take-off run that must be available to satisfy the take-off requirements:
options: a. must not be less than the gross take-off distance to 50 ft
b. must not be less than 1.15 times the gross take-off distance to 50 ft
c. must not be less than 1.25 times the gross take-off distance to 50 ft
d. must not be less than 1.3 times the gross take-off distance to 50 ft
questions.explanation: For a Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with no stopway or clearway, the take-off run available (TORA) must be at least 1.25 times the gross take-off distance to 50 ft. This provides a safety margin to account for variations in pilot technique, aircraft performance, and environmental conditions.

questions.question: For a single-engine Class B aircraft, the rotation speed $V_{R}$:
options: a. must not be less than $1.1V_{C1}$
b. must not be less than $V_{S}$
c. must not be less than $1.2V_{MC}$
d. must not be less than $V_{MC}$
questions.explanation: For a single-engine Class B aircraft, the rotation speed (VR) must not be less than the stalling speed (VS). This ensures that the aircraft has sufficient speed to generate lift and become airborne safely. VR must be at least equal to VS to prevent stalling during rotation and initial climb.

questions.question: For a single-engine Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with stopway:
options: a. the TOD 1.3 must not exceed the ASDA
b. the TOD must not exceed the ASDA 1.3
c. the TOD x 1.25 must not exceed the ASDA
d. the TOD must not exceed the ASDA 1.25
questions.explanation: For a single-engine Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with stopway, the Take-off Distance (TOD) multiplied by 1.25 must not exceed the Accelerate-Stop Distance Available (ASDA). This ensures that if an engine failure occurs during take-off, the aircraft can either continue the take-off or stop safely within the available runway and stopway distance.
